Message.Title: Africans and Arabs still keep slaves today
Message.Msg: Search: Modern Slavery When a ship carrying hundreds of people was recently turned away from Benin, Africa, officials suspected that the children on board were human slaves. The incident once again brought attention to the problem of slavery. At this moment, millions of men, women, and children—roughly twice the population of Rhode Island—are being held against their will as modern-day slaves. Sometimes referred to as bonded laborers (because of the debts owed their masters), public perception of modern slavery is often confused with reports of workers in low-wage jobs or inhumane working conditions. However, modern-day slaves differ from these workers because they are actually held in physical bondage (they are shackled, held at gunpoint, etc.). Modern-day slaves can be found laboring as servants or concubines in Sudan, as child "carpet slaves" in India, or as cane-cutters in Haiti and southern Pakistan, to name but a few instances. According to Anti-Slavery International, the world's oldest human rights organization, there are currently over 20 million people in bondage. Where does this slavery take place? Who are the faces behind these atrocities? Slave Trading on Africa's West Coast The slave trade in Africa was officially banned in the early 1880s, but forced labor continues to be practiced in West and Central Africa today. UNICEF estimates that 200,000 children from this region are sold into slavery each year. Many of these children are from Benin and Togo, and are sold into the domestic, agricultural, and sex industries of wealthier, neighboring countries such as Nigeria and Gabon. The most recent incident involved the MV Etireno, which was refused from ports in Gabon and Cameroon. When the ship reached Cotonou, Benin, in April, 2001, police began an investigation of the captain and crew. More adults than children were believed to be aboard.
Exposing yourself for the race baiting moron that you are is priceless Hooz.

Message.Title: Boeing 777 crashed landed in San Francisco.
Message.Msg: I saw pictures of crash on NHK World TV. It looks bad. No report on injuries or fatalities yet. The Boeing 777 jet flight originated in South Korea, Inchon Airport.

It should go up 20%, didn't you see just how well that aircraft held up? Nothing goes well when you land the tail first. That aircraft is in remarkable shape. Order book should excel based on what we see there.

SAN FRANCISCO (AP) -- An Asiana Airlines flight from Seoul, South Korea, crashed while landing at San Francisco International Airport on Saturday, forcing passengers to jump down the emergency inflatable slides to safety. It was not immediately known whether there were any injuries. The Boeing 777 was supposed to land on runway 28 left at the airport, said Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Laura Brown. She said the sequence of events was still unclear, but it appeared the plane landed and then crashed. A video clip posted to YouTube shows smoke coming from a silver-colored jet on the tarmac. Passengers could be seen jumping down the inflatable emergency slides. Television footage showed debris strewn about the tarmac and pieces of the plane lying on the runway.
I think I agree, shock. (I'll know for sure AFTER some facts come in :-)

Message.Title: Probably pilot error
Message.Msg: My guess ... they were cleared for an approach to 28R, with a sidestep to 28L. Glide path guidance had to be switched to 28L (was it done?). Otherwise they had no glide path guidance, and the pilot did it visually and came in obviously too low. Tragic. Or, kept 28R guidance set in and that guided him too low or not accurately .... I believe 28R sticks out further, so the glide path would come in lower if using 28L ... have to check the approach. Also, it appears the FO was flying since the plane landed "right" of centerline. That's a tendency ... so it is just a first guess. Tragic ... but not Boeing's fault as my first guess.
Thanks for the insight. Speculation though it is, at leased it's based on Something! :-)

Message.Msg: According to Stripes publication: Citing a Food and Drug Administration test that found some brands of electronic cigarettes contain potentially toxic chemicals, the Air Force surgeon general’s office last week categorized them as “tobacco products,” and thus prohibits their use in most Air Force facilities. Topic.Title: 777 crash landing NSTA to boeing fix your planes

Message.Msg: Air France Airbus A-330 crashed 6/1/2009 with the loss of 228 souls.

Inteeresting on video- shows runway 28 Left ,etc. Closeup of rear bulkhead area ** seems* to show bulkhead split in middle, and surrounding body torn/ripped in a staggered.curve, which **seems* to indicate the 'failure" ( being torn off ) is/was NOT at a production break or attachment / circular frame area, but instead some sort of sideways and up displacement of aft section. Note rudder is on left side of runway approach and horiz stabilizers on right side. - wierd but ** probably * not a fatigue or structural failure from simple flight loads, but more like a tail drag- nose high impact with seawall which is onlky a few feet above runway. It will be interesting to find out the CVR and Black box data.. MY summary- plane was NOT upside down, "cartwheel"was in horizontal semi circular motion , wings were basically intact and NOT torn off, horiz stab which look like and are small wings were torn off. Why that happened is pure speculation at this time.

AFIK- its a flying tail like on 767- The whole stabilizer ( small wing ) can rotate up or down, and relatively small trim "tabs" on trailing edge are used to assist and get very minor changes. On 767 for sure there is a centrally located jack screw driven by a small motor to move the whole stabilizer ( small wings in back for the other posters ) in rotation up or down essentially changing angle of attack re airflow. From NBC news so far “We were approaching perfectly well, but we were too low,” he said. “When the pilot realized it, he put some more gas to correct it, but it was too late, so we hit the runway pretty bad, and we started going up in the air again, and we landed pretty hard." Stefanie Turner was walking to her hotel on the waterfront across from the runway at San Francisco International Airport when she saw a landing plane coming in at a bad angle, its tail very low. "As we were watching, we saw the Asiana flight approaching, and we saw that the angle was wrong," she said. "The tail was too low as it was approaching.”

Update... "One engine and the tail section behind the aft pressure bulkhead became separated from the aircraft. The vertical and both horizontal stabilizers came to rest on the runway before the threshold, while the remainder of the fuselage and wings halted to the left side of the runway. Eyewitnesses described a large brief fireball upon the aircraft landing, and a second large explosion minutes after the impact, with a large, dark plume of smoke rising from the fuselage. Evacuation slides were deployed on one side of the plane, and were used to evacuate the passengers."

Message.Msg: In the visuals it can be seen where the tail hit the seawall. It can also be seen that the wings remained attached, but the tail broke off. At least 2 dead. Several unaccounted for, but in cases of crash landing, often passengers walk away without reporting in.

Topic.Title: Crash plane was 6 years old and reports indicate pilot error

Message.Msg: Now it seems they have accounted for all but one passenger, still reporting 2 deceased.

Message.Title: Popular Boeing 777 Has Had Strong Safety Record
Message.Msg: San Francisco Accident Punctuates One of the Safest Periods of U.S. Civil Aviation. So contrary to the lying occurring from the shorts---aircraft travel has maintained a very good safety record.

I should have checked the notams on the internet, but the rationale remains the same. They were flying a visual, and I would guess still a sidestep to 28L since SFO likes to depart 28R. Assume the pilots knew well ahead of time about the notams telling them that they weren't going to have approaches that had glidepaths, then they had to use the VASI system which should have worked to visually do it, if used correctly. Or, possibly set up the automation on the aircraft to assist the approach as an aid ... still they needed to monitor the approach visually. Still it doesn't seem it is going to be a Boeing problem. I hope it wasn't because they were surprised at the last minute as to the conditions of the approaches at SFO, or the non flying pilot had his head in the cockpit trying to set up some automation at the last minute.
MSNBC........only an insane Marxist Communist would watch that channel.

Message.Title: Only 2nd major accident of a 777 in 18 years
Message.Msg: The 777 has a fantastic record," said Tom Haueter, who retired last year from the National Transportation Safety Board, where he was the head of aviation accident investigations.
